abstracts.cdata!:
The Jelgava District Heating (DH)
            Rehabilitation Project has substantially met the original
            objectives. The Project has taught some valuable lessons
            which concern demand forecasts, tariff and regulatory
            policies, competition with gas, evaluation of DH systems as
            whole, and the need to resolve pending liabilities of the
            beneficiary before the commencement of implementation. 1)
            Future DH projects should scrutinize demand projections and
            the factors which affect demand very carefully. Greater
            efforts to identify new DH consumers should also be
            undertaken. Demand forecast analysis should also consider
            the results of social assessments. 2) Appropriate tariff
            policies play an important role in maintaining DH consumers
            and thus preserving the viability of DH systems. Maintaining
            competitiveness with other heat providers should be a prime
            goal of regulators and incorporated in a DH tariff policy, a
            clear and consistent regulatory policy based on long-term
            least-cost provision of heat should be adopted at the
            beginning of the Project. 3) When designing a DH project, it
            is important to properly assess risks associated with the
            potential for competition from gas or other alternatives to
            DH. 4) The design of DH projects should consider how to
            optimize the whole DH system within a city, and not just the
            DH assets owned by a given DH company. 5) The issue of the
            gas debt should have been more clearly addressed at the
            project appraisal stage.
